Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Health-Beacons: Flexible Wearable Health and Activity Tracker for Smart Living
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps project aims at designing Health-Beacons, which are flexible wearable devices for health and activity tracking. Health-Beacons can provide valuable insights into a user's daily activity and health patterns, thus creating proactive awareness for improved wellness, health performance and quality of living. The benefiting community includes elderly people and their relatives, athletes, doctors and caregivers, among others. Commercial success of Health-Beacons technology will significantly reduce federal expenditures on Medicare, Medicaid and other health/wellness management programs for millions of active people as well as the elderly generation in the United States. The broader impacts of this project also include educational and outreach activities, multi-disciplinary student training, and promoting innovation and entrepreneurship culture among Missouri S&T students.

The Health-Beacons system will integrate innovative bendable skin conformable electronics, multi-modal sensing, and machine learning-based sensor data analytics, in collaboration with wireless communications through Bluetooth beacons. The key novelty lies in flexible electronics, intelligent sensor data analytics techniques, and predictive modeling. Through contextual information visualization and interaction, Health-Beacons will be made user-friendly to allow interfacing with a multitude of technologies. The developed system will provide users with a quantified smart living dashboard based on health and activity tracking that can also be displayed on smartphones or smartwatches. Considering that wearable technology for health and wellness management is still in its infancy with early adopters, the Health-Beacons project will create a new body of knowledge in wearable computing, sensor data analytics, and smart healthcare.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this I-Corps Teams project is to design Health-Beacons wearable system for health and activity tracking. Health-Beacons can provide valuable insights into a user's daily activity and health patterns, thus creating proactive awareness for improved wellness, health performance and quality of living. The benefiting community includes elderly people and their relatives, athletes, doctors and caregivers, among others. Commercial success of Health-Beacons technology will significantly reduce federal expenditures on Medicare, Medicaid and other health/wellness management programs for millions of elderly population as well as healthy/active people in the United States. The main efforts were in validating the commercialization hypothesis with the help of extensive customer discovery, and in generating business model by leveraging intensive training and coaching provided by I-Corps mentors. As part of this project, 110 customer interviews (98 in-person, 9 on phone, and 3 on video chat) were conducted during the cohort training, and 160 additional customer interviews after the completion of the cohort till the project end date. The interviewed customers were mostly involved with cognitive and physical care and rehabilitation at-home and included the following stakeholders: doctors (neurologists, surgeons and physicians); registered nurses, directors and managers of specific departments in hospitals; home care-giving company officials and caregivers; relatives to patients of stroke and dementia; elderly people over age 70; professors and researchers in rehabilitation science; founders and CEOs of two healthcare companies; etc.

 

Intellectual Merit: The proposed Health-Beacons system integrates innovative technology, such as multi-modal sensing, machine learning based sensor data analytics, and wireless communications to Bluetooth beacons lightly deployed in the environment. The wearable devices can be worn on multiple positions on the body. Health-Beacons is capable of detecting user movements, Activities of Daily Living (ADL) or Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL), physical and cognitive health conditions, and quality of ambient environment around users. The key novelty lies in embedded sensor technology along with intelligent sensor data analytics algorithms and predictive modeling. The main outcomes include: (i) design and development of custom multi-modal sensing wearable device and sensor embedded smart chair; (ii) improved activity detection and task quality assessment algorithms with wearable sensor data; (iii) new algorithm to detect user’s sedentary activities and emotion states with the smart chair; and (iv) pilot study with a small cohort of cognitive impaired patients (with complete IRB and HIPAA compliance).

 

Broader impact: The simple to use, but powerful Health-Beacons system with wearable has the potential for transforming the commercial product market for quantified health and daily activity tracking. The innovation comes from the fact that the Health-Beacons system improves data analytic capabilities of smart health and wellness management. This will greatly benefit not only elderly people and their relatives but also normal or active people, athletes, doctors and caregivers. Moreover, commercial potential of this technology will effectively help in proactive awareness of health in daily lives, thus significantly reducing healthcare costs for millions of active people as well as elderly population in the United States alone. Such marketplaces are of great interest to the federal and state governments because of concerns about rapidly growing budget and annual spending on Medicare, Medicaid, and other health/wellness management costs. The I-Corps project had important impact not only on relevant fields of research and market (wearable technologies, healthcare, human-centered environments), but also on educational and outreach objectives at Missouri S&T.
